Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 231,.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 231, Section 85 (Negligence actions)
Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 231,.proposition: As a result of Defendant's negligence, Plaintiff suffered damages, including property damage, medical expenses, and lost wages.

Scott v. Boston Housing Authority, 445 N.raw_text: Scott v. Boston Housing Authority, 445 N.E.2d 1098 (Mass. 1983)
Scott v. Boston Housing Authority, 445 N.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff to maintain his property in a safe manner and to prevent foreseeable harm.
Scott v. Boston Housing Authority, 445 N.case_name: Elliot v. Green Bus Lines, Inc.
Scott v. Boston Housing Authority, 445 N.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether the infancy tolling provision in CPLR 208 applies to an application to confirm an arbitration award under CPLR 7510. It does not address premises liability, duties of care regarding maintenance of property, or foreseeability of harm. The case is about procedural time limits in arbitration-confirmation proceedings, not about a defendant’s duty to maintain property safely, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Scott v. Boston Housing Authority, 445 N.relevant_excerpt:
The toll for infancy prescribed in CPLR 208 does not apply to an application pursuant to CPLR 7510 to confirm an arbitration award.
...
The special provisions governing applications for confirmations of awards in arbitration are expressly prescribed in CPLR article 75. CPLR 7510 provides that the application to confirm an award must be made within one year after its delivery.

Williamson v. Lavoie, 543 N.E.2d 219 (Ma.raw_text: Williamson v. Lavoie, 543 N.E.2d 219 (Mass. App. Ct. 1998)

Williamson v. Lavoie, 543 N.E.2d 219 (Ma.case_name: Adman Products Co. v. Federal Insurance
Williamson v. Lavoie, 543 N.E.2d 219 (Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance coverage/declaratory judgment case about an insurer’s duty to defend and the application of property damage exclusions. It does not analyze premises liability, negligence, or any independent duty of care owed by the defendant to maintain property safely or prevent foreseeable harm. The only discussion of “negligent maintenance” appears as a characterization of the underlying complaint, not as a ruling on the existence or scope of such a duty; thus it does not support the stated proposition.
Williamson v. Lavoie, 543 N.E.2d 219 (Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Count I alleges that Adman is liable for negligent maintenance of its building. Count II alleges liability on a bailment theory. Count III alleges breach of contract for failure to procure insurance. The parties agree that counts II and III do not allege facts falling within policy coverage.”

Day v. Raytheon, 770 N.E.2d 918 (Mass. 2.proposition: Defendant's breach of duty was the direct and proximate cause of the damage sustained by Plaintiff's car.
Day v. Raytheon, 770 N.E.2d 918 (Mass. 2.case_name: Hochstedler v. St. Joseph County Solid Waste Management District
Day v. Raytheon, 770 N.E.2d 918 (Mass. 2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the validity and characterization of a mandatory recycling fee imposed by a waste management district and related constitutional/statutory challenges. It does not involve a negligence claim, duty of care, or any discussion of direct or proximate causation of damage to a plaintiff’s car or any other property damage. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant’s breach of duty was the direct and proximate cause of damage to a plaintiff’s car.
Day v. Raytheon, 770 N.E.2d 918 (Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: In the present case, the mandatory recycling fee represents a specific payment for curbside recycling services and is associated with the necessary costs of the services rendered. In addition, the fee is uniformly imposed upon all residential property owners to which the ordinance applies. Accordingly, even though the fee is compulsory, we hold that the mandatory recycling fee is a fee and not a tax.

Christian v. Murray Brothers Nurseries,.raw_text: Christian v. Murray Brothers Nurseries, 879 N.E.2d 671 (Mass. 2005)
Christian v. Murray Brothers Nurseries,.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to secure the ladder properly and address the known safety risk it posed to Plaintiff's vehicle.
Christian v. Murray Brothers Nurseries,.case_name: Bank of America, N.A. v. Ping
Christian v. Murray Brothers Nurseries,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns mortgage priority, termination of a revolving line of credit mortgage, and equitable subrogation between banks. It does not address any duty to secure a ladder, vehicle safety risks, premises liability, or any analogous negligence duty. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that a defendant breached a duty by failing to secure a ladder or protect a plaintiff’s vehicle from that hazard.
Christian v. Murray Brothers Nurseries,.relevant_excerpt: “Here, Bank of America failed to take any affirmative steps to terminate the Bank One Mortgage after Bank of America had paid in full the line of credit. And, as a result, Bank One held open Ping’s line of credit, and Bank One continued to advance Ping funds from that account. … Given the plain meaning of the Credit Agreement and the mortgage that secured it, it was incumbent on Bank of America to secure release of the Bank One Mortgage as a condition of its new loan to Ping.”
